text: my father became ill and he had a
company in Detroit which was one of the
first Distributors of imported
automobiles but he was Ill this was a
much smaller company than I had dealt
with um and worked with and he always
saw me as standing on his shoulders not
following in his footsteps but when he
became ill and needed 247 care and it
was the early 80s and the recession in
the US was a depression in Detroit I had
a choice I was living in California I
was married I had two stepchildren I had
a career there I had these various
boards I was on and if I didn't jump in
and turn that business around he was
going to have to go in a nursing home
and he was there for me when I needed
him when he was the only person who
understood that I wasn't going for the
classic 1950s woman's lifestyle and he
was my big Advocate there then and I
needed to be there for him now so I took
over the company I commuted from San
Francisco I turned it around Quinn
tupled it enabled him to stay at home
till he died ultimately sold the
companies and at the same time to to
keep the earnings coming into our
household I started an independent
Consulting practice and had clients in
San Antonio and New York and Minneapolis
while I was running the company in
Michigan and living in San Francisco and
serving on the national Commission on
Social Security reform and and I kind of
think I made a difference um in all
those um
arenas
